title: How to Clean a Rubber Gym Floor

steps.headline: Vacuum the floor with a rolling, brush-style vacuum.
steps.description: Before mopping or using an automatic scrubber on your rubber gym floor, it’s helpful to first vacuum up some of the surface dirt and debris. Make sure that you use a vacuum with rolling, soft brush bristles (such as a vacuum with a carpet setting), as this type of vacuum is less likely to scuff or damage the rubber material. While it won’t be as quick or effective as vacuuming, you can also use a broom and dustpan to sweep up dirt and debris.

steps.headline: Use a scraper to get stuck-on items off the gym floor.
steps.description: If there’s anything stuck on your rubber gym floor, such as gum, you can use a plastic or wood scraper to loosen it off the flooring. To do this, gently push the scraper under the stuck-on material, angling the scraper down towards the floor while pushing the material up. Make sure that you don’t press down too hard into the floor, as the scraper could scuff or damage the rubber material. Once you’ve lifted the stuck-on material, you can use a vacuum to clean it up off the flooring.

steps.headline: Disinfect your rubber gym floor with a homemade solution.
steps.description: In a large bucket, mix 1 cup (240 mL) of white vinegar with 1 gallon (3.8 L) of hot water. Then, use a cleaning rag or sponge mop to spread the cleaning solution across the gym floor. The hot water and vinegar solution will disinfect your gym floor without damaging the rubber material. To leave your flooring with a fresh, clean smell, add a squeeze of lemon or a few drops of your favorite fresh-smelling essential oil (such as eucalyptus) to the disinfecting solution. If the floors are particularly dirty in some areas, you can use a soft bristle hand brush to gently scrub the disinfecting solution into the flooring.

steps.headline: Mix warm water with ⁄4 cup (59 mL) of a neutral pH cleaner.
steps.description: To create a rubber-safe cleaning solution, fill your mop bucket with warm water. Then, add 1 tablespoon (15 mL) to ⁄4 cup (59 mL) of a neutral pH floor cleaner or dish soap, depending on how large your rubber gym floor is. When looking for a rubber-safe floor cleaner, look for cleaner with "neutral pH" on the bottle. For example, OdoBan Neutral pH Floor Cleaner, Bona Free and Simple Neutral pH Cleaner, and Zep Neutral Floor Cleaner are all great options. Avoid using a solvent-based cleaner, such as hardwood floor cleaner or bleach, as these can damage and corrode the rubber on your gym floor. Try to use as little floor cleaner or dish soap as possible. While both of these options are gentle on rubber flooring, they can leave a small amount of residue after each cleaning that can build up over time and damage your gym floor.

steps.headline: Mop the floor with a nylon or sponge mop.
steps.description: Dip the end of a nylon or sponge mop into the bucket with the cleaning solution. Then, starting at the end of the room farthest away from the door, mop the rubber gym floor thoroughly. Work your way towards the door so you don’t have to walk over any flooring you’ve already moped. You may need to spend a little extra time mopping in harder to reach areas or scrubbing up touch dirt spots or stains. Textured mop pads may scratch or damage the rubber, so make sure you use a nylon or sponge mop to protect the gym floor material.

steps.headline: Change out the soapy water as needed.
steps.description: If you’re mopping a large area of rubber gym floor, you may need to change out the cleaning solution if it starts to get brown and murky. To change the water, dump the dirty water out into the sink and refill the bucket with warm water. Then, remix the water with your neutral pH floor cleaner or dish soap. Mopping with dirty water can make your floors dirtier instead of cleaning them. Therefore, it’s important that you change the water to avoid spreading germs and dirt.

steps.headline: Allow the rubber gym floor to air dry before walking on it.
steps.description: Once you’ve mopped the entire rubber gym floor area, leave the floor to air dry completely. Walking on the floor while it’s still wet can track dirt and debris across the floor and make it stick to the floor. Allowing the floor to air dry will also give them chemicals in the soap time to kill germs.

steps.headline: Clean your rubber gym floor daily or weekly.
steps.description: To keep your gym floors sanitized and dirt-free, make sure that you clean the floors at least once per week. If your gym is used frequently or there are some areas that get a lot of traffic, mop daily to keep the floor free of germs and to keep sweat from damaging the material.

steps.headline: Get an automatic floor scrubber with soft bristles.
steps.description: If you want to use an automatic floor scrubber to clean your rubber gym floor, make sure that you choose a machine with soft bristles. Using a floor scrubber with hard, tough bristles can leave scuff marks on the rubber flooring. Therefore, it’s important that you get a soft brush scrubber to protect the rubber material. Using a scrubber is a great option because it both dispenses clean water and sucks up dirty water as you push. Automatic floor scrubbers cost anywhere from $85 USD for a small, personal use machine to $1,000 for an industrial performance machine.

steps.headline: Add warm water to your scrubber according to the instructions.
steps.description: For most automatic scrubbing machines, you’ll add hot water to the machine by opening a compartment on top of the machine and pouring in the amount of water indicated in the instruction manual. Every brand and model of scrubber is different, however, so make sure that you follow the instructions for your specific scrubber. Using warm to hot water will kill more germs than using cold water.

steps.headline: Use a floor cleaner for every 5th cleaning.
steps.description: If you haven’t recently mopped with floor cleaner, you can add a small amount into the machine (or onto the floor, depending on the instructions for your machine) along with the warm water. If you’ve recently mopped your rubber gym floor with a neutral pH floor cleaner or dish soap, however, avoid adding any, as there’s likely still residue from the soapy solution on the floor that can keep the scrubber from drawing impurities out of the rubber floor. As a general rule of thumb, only use floor cleaner with your scrubber every 5th clean. While it’s generally safe to use cleaner every day when you mop, the scrubber uses more force to clean the floor and can embed cleaning solution residue further into the porous rubber floor.

steps.headline: Push your floor scrubber across the entire rubber gym floor surface.
steps.description: Once you’ve added water and cleaning solution (if needed), plug in your automatic scrubber. Then, push the scrubber slowly across the entire floor to ensure that every area gets sanitized. Depending on the brand and type of scrubber you’re using, you may need to manually press a button to dispense water and then press another to suck up the water. Make sure that you read the instructions carefully before using the scrubber.

steps.headline: Use the scrubber to clean your rubber gym floor daily or weekly.
steps.description: To keep your gym clean and sanitized, use your automatic scrubber at least once per week. If your gym gets a lot of traffic, use the scrubber daily to ensure the floor is clean and germ-free. While it’s generally safe to use an automatic scrubber daily, some types of rubber gym flooring are more porous and soft. If this is the case, use your scrubber every other day or once per week, mopping in between uses to keep the floors clean.
